org.gearvrf.animation

Class GVRAnimationEngine

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.gearvrf.animation.GVRAnimationEngine

  • public class GVRAnimationEngine
extends java.lang.Object
    This class runs animations. You can animate changes in just about any property of a scene object.

    The animation engine is an optional part of GVRF: to use it, you must call getInstance(GVRContext) to lazy-create the singleton.

    You can stop(GVRAnimation) a running animation at any time, but usually you will either

    • Use setRepeatCount(0) to 'schedule' termination at the end of the current repetition, or
    • Set a callback, which allows you to terminate the animation before the next loop.

    • Method Detail

      • getInstance

        public static GVRAnimationEngine getInstance(GVRContext gvrContext)
        The animation engine is an optional part of GVRF: You do have to call getInstance() to lazy-create the singleton.
        Parameters:
        gvrContext - current GVR context

      • start

        public GVRAnimation start(GVRAnimation animation)
        Registers an animation with the engine: It will start running immediately. You will usually use GVRAnimation.start(GVRAnimationEngine) instead of this method: 
         
 new GVRSomeAnimation(object, duration, parameter) //
         .setOnFinish(handler) //
         .start(animationEngine);
        reads better than 
         
 animationEngine.start( //
         new GVRSomeAnimation(object, duration, parameter) //
                 .setOnFinish(handler) //
         );
        Parameters:
        animation - an animation
        Returns:
        The animation that was passed in.

      • stop

        public void stop(GVRAnimation animation)
        Stop the animation, even if it is still running: the animated object will be left in its current state, not reset to the start or end values. This is probably not what you want to do! Usually you will either
        • Use setRepeatCount(0) to 'schedule' termination at the end of the current repetition, or
        • Set a callback, which allows you to terminate the animation before the next loop.
        You may want to stop() an animation if you are also removing the animated object the same time. For example, you may be spinning some sort of In Progress object. In a case like this, stopping in mid-animation is harmless.
        Parameters:
        animation - an animation
